div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.-Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.)
N.B.-Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.-P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices: 36, New Broad-street. E.C.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS CO., LIMITED. (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, EC.)

div.head: BIRTH.
div.p: CRAIG.
- On April 13, at Matarieh, the wife of James
Ireland Craig, of a son.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, APRIL 14, 1905..

div.head: THE ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY.
div.p: Abyssinia, our immediate neighbour in the Sudan, must inevitably be drawn nearer and nearer to Egypt by commercial ties, and the recent link that has been forged between the two countries by the participation of the National Bank of Egypt in the new State bank of Abyssinia is destined to bring the two countries into close touch with one another. Another and still more important link between Abyssinia and the Valley of the Nile will be the Ethiopian railway, the third section of which will extend from Adis Abeba to the Nile, and a telegram this morning from the Abyssinian capital contains an announcement of the utmost importance as regards the future of this important line of railway.

The object of the negotiations which have been taking place during the past two years, and are still in progress, is to find some means of escape from an intolerable situation, which, while safeguarding the independance of Abyssinia, will secure the construction of the remaining sections of the railway and thus render it possible to develop the mineral, pastoral, and agricultural resources of the Ethiopian Empire. It is natural that Frenchmen should contemplate with extreme reluctance the abandonment of the hope of securing political and commercial predominance in Abyssinia, and hesitate to acquiesce in the rival policy of equal rights for all nations. Three months ago the president of the railway company expressed the hope that the French Government would still be persuaded to make an immediate and powerful effort to obtain satisfaction for the company, and thus make it possible for the enterprise to retain its exclusively French character. More recently the French African Committee adopted resolutions pointing in the direction; but as yet there has been no public indication by the French Government as to whether it is prepared to apply great pressure at Adis Abeba with the object indicated, or whether it intends to accept the advice of the principal French Chambers of Commerce that it should acquiesce in the proposal for placing. the Ethiopian Railway system under international control. Among those who are pressing the former solution on the Government, it is frankly recognised that French influence alone is insufficient to induce the Emperor to change his mind, and the suggestion which is put forward is that since the establishment of the Anglo-French entente cordiale the French Government may reasonably invite the British Government not only to abandon the policy which it has hitherto supported, but to join. with France in inducing the Emperor Menelik to accede to the French demands.

Even if the consideration of British interests be for the moment left on one side, it is not clear what advantage, sufficient to justify further pressure being brought on the Emperor Menelik, France can hope to derive, under the changed conditions of to-day, from the maintenance of the railway as an exclusively French enterprise. No doubt if the whole of the railway from Djibouti to the western frontier of Abyssinia, or even to Adis Abeba, were to be exclusively controlled by France, it would be a potential instrument for the furtherance of French interests. A not unimportant section of the French public is still therefore unwilling to abandon the hope that diplomatic action at Adis Abeba may secure the consent of the Emperor to the construction of the remaining sections of the line as an exclusively French enterprise. The advocates of this view suggest that the friendly relations now existing between the British and the French Governments justify France in asking Great Britain not only to abandon the opposition which, it is alleged, Sir John Harrington has hitherto shown to the proposals of the Ethiopian Railway Company, but actively to support those proposals.

Such a suggestion implies a radical misconception of the political conditions at the Abyssinian capital. Apart altogether from the atti tude which may have been adopted by the British Minister Plenipotentiary and his Italian colleague, the central fact of the situation is that since he became acquainted with the terms of the railway agreement of 1902 the Emperor Menelik is himself firmly and unalter ably opposed to any part of the Abyssinian railway system remaining under the exclusive control of a single European Power. There are still many Frenchmen who are apparently unable to realise what a colossal political blunder that agreement was. The French Government insisted on the inclusion of clauses which were, in the words of the President of the Ethiopian Railway Company, "obviously incompatible with the Sovereign rights of the Emperor Menelik."

None of the numerous attempts which have been made to explain away those clauses, or to give them an innocent meaning, have succeeded in removing from the mind of the Emperor the impression that the ultimate object of French policy was to secure at least a political sphere of influence in Abyssinia. British political and commercial interests, which it is the primary duty of the British Government to safeguard, are opposed to the establishment of exclusively French control over the railway. But even were the British Government to lend its diplomatic support to French pretensions, the only result would be to destroy the influence which Sir John Harrington has succeeded in establishing at the Abyssinian Court. Menelik, would not have far to look for support elsewhere, and his notification to the representatives of the powers, as announced in to-day's tele grams, shows that he is determined to settle the question in his own way, as he is well aware how the influences of European civilisation, when materialising in the form of railways, telegraphs, and financial assistance, all provided by foreigners, may be turned into financial control and industrial domina tion, and finally powerful instruments of political leverage subserving the ends of foreign ambition,
A

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET. REPORT OF FIGHT UNCONFIRMED. POSITION OF FLEET.

div.p: H.M.S. cruiser "Sutlej" passed the Baltic feet 550 miles to the north-east of Singapore, hence Dutch report regarding the fighting near the Anamba Islands is discredit. (R.)
The report of the fighting between the Rus- sian and Japanese fleets near the Anamba Islands is not confirmed. (Havas.)
The P. & O. "Nubia", sighted the Baltic fleet on Monday, 200 miles south-east of Saigon. The fleet was steaming north-east. This disposes of the report of fighting near the Anamba Islands. (Reuter)

div.head: THE ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY. NEGUS'S FIRM ATTITUDE.

div.p: The Emperor Menelik has summoned the representatives of the Powers to his Palace, and notified them that, unless they come to an agreement regarding the extension of the rail- way towards Ababa, such agreement providing for the maintenance of the independence of Abyssinia and the internationalisation of the railway, he will construct such extension him- self, his decision being final.

This fact is noteworthy in view of M. Deleasse's speech on the 2nd inst., when he strongly objected to the internationalisation of even the second section—the construction of which Menelik had already authorised—and declared that both should retain a French character, frr which a French subsidy was to be granted. (Reuter.)

In connection with the visit of the French fleet to London, the Corporation will entertain the officers at the Guildhall on the 10th August. Arrangements are also being made for the sailors to march through the city. The Atlantic Squadron will visit Brest early in July. (Reuter.)

The remarks of Mr. Chamberlain, in his speech at the Liberal Union Club, praising Lord Lansdowne's exposition of the fiscal policy, which the latter made in the House of Lords on Tuesday when he repudiated pro- tective taxation on food, are regarded as likely to lead to the adoption of a "modus vivendi" between the opposing sections of Ministerialists. (Reuter.)

div.head: PANAMA CANAL. WORKS TO BE COMMENCED.

div.p: It has been decided to commence the Panama Canal works immediately, and to engage 2,000 Chinese and 2,000 Japanese coolies. (Reuter.)
Their Majesties left the Balearic Islands for Algiers, where they will stay two days. (R.)
The British Admiral gave a dinner, in honor of Emperor William and the King of Greece. The Emperor has left for Messina. (Havas.)
Tho S.S. "Hindoo," having given a bond, has been released. (Reuter.)
Craven Stakes- 1, St. Oswald ; 2, Shilfa; 3, Ray Hastings. (Reuter.)

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Central position. Under English management.
The Hellenic Assize Court will open its session at Alexandria on May 14.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail
div.p: will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria at 8.30 a.m. on Sunday.
The Maltese Benevolent Society acknowledges with thanks the receipt of P.T. 200 from an anonymous donor.

div.head: Port Arthur Garrison.
div.p: Twenty officers of the Port Arthurtr garrison-left Alexandria to-day by the Russian steamer for Odessa.

div.head: Popular University
div.p: A concert reserved to adherents of tho university will be held on Monday next, commencing at 9.15 p.m.

div.head: Slave Trade
div.p: The Slave Trade Repression Department freed eleven slaves during March, ten of whom were Sudanese and one Circassian.

div.head: Upper Egypt Hotels
div.p: The Council of Ministers will approve of the formation of the Upper Egypt Hotels Company at its next meeting.

div.head: Sudden Death
div.p: A watchman employed by a wood merchant on the Marina was found dead yesterday. Death was due to natural causes.

div.head: Murderer Sentenced
div.p: Abou el Ella was sentenced to hard labour for life yesterday by tho Native Tribunal at Alexandria for the murder of a fellah in Behora province.

div.head: New Company
div.p: There is some talk of the flotation of a new company which intends to construct dwelling-houses in Cairo in view of the prevailing scarcity and the high rent of dwellings.

div.head: Wreck
div.p: The Greek steamer, "Demetrious," which was recently stranded on the coast, near Aboukir, left dry-dock yesterday after being examined. Teo damage done* to the vessel is estimated at £2,000.

div.head: Belgian Consulate
div.p: Our Constantinople Correspondent states that the Belgian Lega- tion there has applied to the Sublime Porte for the exequatur for M. G. Riches, who has beenn appointed Consul at Port Said.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: l2 vessels passed through the Canal on the 11th inst., 6 of which were British, 2 German, 1 Dutch, 1 Austrian, 1 Norwegian, 1 Greek. The receipts for the day were frs. 312,810.49, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 3,572,362.10.

div.head: Stray and Ownerless Dogs
div.p: found in the Darb el Ahmar quarter of Cairo during the night of Saturday and dawn of Sunday, and in the Gamalieh district during the night of Sunday and dawn of Monday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: "The Suez Canal, its Origin, Construction, and Administration."
div.p: The recent address given by Col. Sir Howard Vincent, M.P., to the London Chamber of Commerce has been published in pamphlet from, price 1s, and copies maybe obtained at Diemer's Library, Cairo.

div.head: Inhuman Daughter-In-Law.
div.p: A native woman fell from the roof of her house at Chatby and sustained serious injuries. On being removed to hospital, she stated that while on the roof with her daughter-in-law the latter gave her a push, which sent her headlong into the street. The daughter-in-law has been arrested.

div.head: Alhambra
div.p: The members of Gatti's circus troupe, having partly replaced the properties lost in the recent fire at the Abbas Helmy Theatre, are to commence a series of performances at the Alhambra tomorrow evening. The usual circus entertainment will be given. The theatre will be closed tonight for the necessary preparations to be made.

The Benefit Performance of the Giuntini circus on behalf of the members of Gatti's circus, victims of the fire at the Abbas Helmy Theatre, was very successful and the sale of tickets realised frs. 4,650, which sum has been handed to the Italian Consulate. All the ex- penses of the performance have been paid by Mr. Rossano, the philanthropic stockbroker.

div.head: Well-Directed Liberality
div.p: On the occasion of the marriage of his daughter, Idris Bey Ragheb gave a donation of fifty pounds to the fund of benevolence of the National Grand Lodge of Egypt. One third of this sum goes towards the upkeep and education of orphan children, one third in annuities to aged and distressed widows, and one third to relieve other forms of distress.

div.head: St. Mark's Jubilee of Consecration
div.p: In connection with the commemoration of the jubilee of St. Mark's on the 25th inst., some may be glad to know of a series of very inte resting articles on the history of St Mark's chaplaincy, written by Rear-Admiral Sir Mas- sie Blomfield, K.C.M.G., in "Bible Lands"—a quarterly paper of the Jerusalem and the East Mission. "Bible Lands" can be ordered through Canon Ward. The subscription is 1s. per annum.

div.head: Bandmann-Dallas Opera Company
div.p: Owing to the great demand for seats for the performance of "A Country Girl" by the Bandmann-Dallas Opera Company at the Eldorado Theatre, Port Said, on the 20th inst., it was found necessary to open the booking office yesterday, two days in advance of the advertised date for booking. Those desirous of getting good seats should reserve them at once, as they are all being rapidly snapped up.

div.head: End of the Season
div.p: Spring has begun to make itself felt in Cairo, and although the rays of the sun remind one already of the coming summer heat, the weather can only be termed delightful. But with the advent of spring our visitors leave the land of the Pharaohs, and carriage after carriage, bearing passengers and luggage, may have been seen in the Cairo streets during the past few days. In the hotels the furniture of some of the rooms is already being stored away, and oven the number of carriages is being reduced, —all signs that the season is nearing its end.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage, Ramleh
div.p: The beautiful weather at Alexandria just now is attracting a number of visitors to the seashore, and the fashionable Beau Rivage Hotel is being well patronised. Under the direction of Mr. G. Runckewitz, formerly manager of the Grand Hotel Weber, in Antwerp, and tho Therapia Summer Palace, in Constantinople, who has taken the Beau Rivage on lease for several years, many improvements and alterations have been made for the comfort of the hotel's clients, and splendid accommodation may be obtained for social functions, fetes, and ban- quets at the hotel, where also promenaders may enjoy afternoon tea in the garden or on the terrace. The excellent cuisine is a feature at this hostelry, and a reliable European service throughout has been instituted by the management.

div.head: Mishap on the Line
div.p: The express which leaves Cairo at midday was an hour late yes- terday in arriving at Alexandria owing to a mishap to a child. While the latter was leaning out of a carriage window by Calioub another train passed, and it is supposed the child received a knock and was thrown out on to the line between the two trains. Both the trains were going at full speed and it is extraordinary that the child was not fatally injured. The train was brought to a standstill and reversed in order to pick up the child, who was found close to Culioub. Scander Pasha Fehmy hap- pened to be on the train and showed great energy in directing the operations. When the child was discovered it was found that she had been badly cut about the head. After being bandaged up and receiving first aid the victim was put on the train and conveyod to Alexandria.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Abani Pasha, Minister of War, arrived at Alexandria from Cairo yesterday.
H.E. the Governor went to Montazah this morning and attended prayers at the Mosque there in company with H.H. tho Khedive.
Sig de Martini, Civil Governor of Erythrea, is expected at Alexandria on the 22nd inst. He willspend a few days in Cairo before proceeding to Massowah.
Marquis Salvago-Raggi, Italian Diplomatic Agent, and Count Sorragna, Consul, returned to Cairo yesterday after seeing tho Duke of the Abruzzi off.
Baron Acton, Italian Consul-General at Alexandria, is expected back from Leghorn on the 23rd inst.
A native contemporary states that Hamada Pasha, local Director of Customs at Alexandria, is to be transferred to the Wakfs Adminiatration.
Mr. Ninci, commercial manager of the Sucreries d'Egypte Company at Alexandria, left Alexandria yesterday for Italy by the Florio-Rubattino S.S. "Memfi"on three months' leave of absence.

Among the visitors staying at the Beau- Rivage Hotel are : Lieut-Col. and Mrs. M. Peake, Capt. and Mrs. W. H. Rotheram, Mr. and Mrs. L. Davis, Mr. Edw. Burley, Mr. R. H. Willan, Mr. and Mrs. P. W. Stout, Mrs. and Miss Young, Mr. and Mrs. C. Lloyd, Mr. and Mrs. E. Herbert, Mr. J. F. Kershaw, and Miss A. Reid.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice Mr. F. Atkinson, Mr. H. J. Ankersmit, Mr. Roberts and party, Mr. Zalotznitzky, Baron von Ahlefeldt, Mr. C. von Ahlefeldt, Capt. C. A. Wilding, Mr. and Mrs. Robinson, Mr. Lundberg, Comtesse Arnim, Miss Graeff, Dr. Clair Boyd, Hon. A. J. Davey and family, Mr. C. de Findley and family, Mr. G. Schinas, Mr. Felsmann, Baron and Baronin von Dobeeck, Mr. Jaeger, Lady Richards, Miss Wringfield, Mr. Riddell, Miss Lehr, Mr. and Mrs. Merren, Mrs. Young, Mr. H. Gildemeister, Dr. and Frau, Weber Mr. and Mrs. Bairlein, Baron Berne- witz, Mr. Francken, Frl. Springfeld, Frl. Boutu, Mr. C. F. Dalaing.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.
xxxxx-1x.7

div.head: ANOTHER BALTIC SQUADRON. SAILING FOR THE EAST.
div.p: I learn on excellent authority that a fourth squadron of the Baltic Fleet will shortly set out for the Far East, and that it will include two new battleships which have only been launched quite recently.

div.head: STATE RAILWAYS CONTRACTS.
div.p: With reference to our article yesterday on the State Railways, we understand that at present the orders for rolling stock are as follows:-
Delivered on in 1965 order. Locomiotives. North British Loco. Co. Glasgow 15 32 Franco-Belgian Co. Belgium 4 6 Henstal & Co., Cassel, Germany -—- 15 Ateliers de Cail, France -—- 10 -—- ——- 19 63

Coaching vehicles. Metropolitan Carriage and Wagon Co., Birmingham 9 105 Goods Wagons. Leeds Forge Co. Leeds (30- ton wagons) -—— 100 Baume and Marpent, Belgium (30-ton wagons) 100 —-— Baume and Marpent, Belgium (10-ton wagons) 1,000 Baume and Marpent, Belginm (cattle trucks) ——— 50 Societe Franco-Belge (brake vans) ——- 40 Mianse & Delane, Belgium (brake vans) ——- 40

The 30-ton goods wagons supplied by Messrs. Baume and Marpent, some of which recently derailed, are having their defects remedied by the above mentioned firm at their own expense. It will be remembered that a similar accident happened to the wagons supplied by the Leeds Forge Company—one of the ten best English firms—last year under the same circumstances.

div.head: SHIPBUILDING AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The contract for the building of four large steam barges for the Delta Navigation Com- pany has been awarded to the Khedivial Mail Steamship and Graving Dock Company, Ltd. We understand the five steam barges previously built by the Khedivial Company, now working on the Nile, are giving the greatest satisfaction to their owners.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
The Khedive attended midday prayers at Montazah Mosque today.
MISSION FOR ENGLISH CATHOLICS.
div.p: During Holy Week the Rev. Father Wulstan Holland, O.F.M., will conduct a short mission for English-speaking Catholics at St. Joseph's Church, in the Ismailieh quarter of Cairo. The mission will open on Palm Sun- day (16th inst.) and will last until Good Fri- day inclusive.

Every evening, at 7.30, there will be sermon and Benediction. On Good Friday morning a military service with sermon will be held at 7.30 and in the evening at 7.30 will close the mission with Stations of the Cross and sermon on the Passion of our Lord.
All those who understand English, civilians and soldiers, residents and visitors, are most earnestly invited to attended these services.

div.head: A.S.C. SKYE MEETING. LAST NIGHT'S LOTTERIES.
div.p: The lotteries at the Khedivial Club last night in connection with to-day's racing gave the following results in Egyptian shillings.
First Race. — Saclavie 55, Wassal 120, Bayard 35, Tonnerre 5, Moulk 30, Derwish 50, Flying Dutchman and Negri 175, Ajax and Hercules 75, Little Korosko and Zarif III. 130.
Second Race.—Sattam 65, Taib 15, Rais 220, Nimrod 5, Firefly and India 90, Au Revoir and Zeidan 320, Spectre 20.
Third Race.—Togo 120, Chinaman 30, Ion 20, Klondyke and Lulu 140, Jupiter 10, Caprice 160, Sir Visto and El Tahawi 320.
Fourth Race.-Amour and Sattam 65, Suleik and Kawkab 190, Vandal 55, Mam- douh 40, Faik 40.

Fifth Race.—Doughan and Sinounou 60, Jupitar and Derwish 40, Timsah 80, Wassal and Spectre 110, Boheme 66, Solforino, Aziz and Saclavie 110, Hercule and Faineant 45, Numir 10, Amik and Flying Dutchman 170.
Sixth Race.—Coeur-de-Lion 30, Boul-de- Neige 150, Au Revoir 120, Mashkour 240, Royalist 45, Caprice 75, Shewiman 50, Rais 50, Suari 85.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Italian S.S. "Singapore," which was due at Alexandria on Sunday morning next, left Messina seven hours behind time and will not arrive before Sunday evening.
The Ellerman S.S. "Anatolia" arrived here on Thursday evening from Odessa.
The Ellerman S.S. "Sardinia" sailed from Malta on Thursday and is expected here from Glasgow and Liverpool on Monday morning.
The S.S. "Trojan Prince" left London on Thursday last, with passengers and general cargo, for Malta and Alexandria.
The S.S. "Roumelia," of the Papayanni Line, arrived in Liverpool yesterday morning.
The Khedivial Mail S.S. "Ismailia" will leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Piraeus, Smyrna, Mitylene and Constantinople.

div.head: DISASTER TO PARCEL POST.
div.p: The boat which was carrying the Parcel Powt from Khartoum to Wad Medani last week, encountered very rough weather on her way. Before she reached Kamlin a strong hurricane blew, and the contents of the boat all went overboard. Fortunately, no lives were lost, the boatmen managing to reach the shore. Efforts were made to recover the lost parcels, and these were partially successful, but many par- cels of silk goods, etc., were completely spoilt, and the merchants to whom these were con- signed have applied to the postal authorities for compensation.

div.head: PUBLIC EXECUTION.
div.p: A Sudanese native, who strangled his wife two weeks ago, was hanged to-day at Wad Medani before a large crowd of spectators.

div.head: NILE TOURISTS.
div.p: During the past two months a great many people have passed up the Nile, some on ordi- nary pleasure trips, some on hunting expedi- tions. The river scenery in winter is very lovely, everything being green on the banks of the river, and the weather being perfect, no rain, little wind, and cool air.

div.head: THE BLUE NILE.
div.p: Many engineers of late have been studying the question of barrages on the Blue Nile; also a canal is projected across the Geziran from Roseires to Klun, which, if constructed, will be of great benefit to three provinces, viz, Sennar, Blue Nile, and Klun.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: Water was first struck on the property of the corporation at 25 feet from the surface This continually increased in volume to about 100 feet, where it rose to 15 feet from the surface. Other heavy bodies of water were met at depths between 100 and 300 feet, when the water stood at 10 feet from the surface. At about 320 feet water was struck rising to 2 1/2 feet above the surface. The water in No. 1 borehole at Khargeh, which has been sunk to four hundred feet, is flowing at a height of 12 feet above the surface of the ground, at the rate of about 150 gallons a minute, and increasing.

There never has been any doubt to the minds of those acquainted with the locality as to the practical certainty of finding artesian water at a certain depth over the whole area. It has, however, been suggested that the available supply would not suffice to irrigate the vast area of cultivable land known to be available. The discovery of large bodies of water to the strata at moderate depths rising to such a depth below the surface as to be easily accessible to ordinary sakiehs or pumps, is of the highest promise, and if the supplies prove to extend over large areas will remove all fear of the necessity of leaving these areas un- cultivated. Also lands on which it might be dangerous to bore artesian wells for fear of injuring existing supplies can be irrigated if these supplies exist nearer the surface.
It appears that these water-bearing beds are well known to the natives, but they in- variably continue to bore until they reach a true artesian supply.

The discovery of the ancient Roman irriga- tion works consisting of lines of subterranean channels and wells leading the water from higher to lower levels in the extreme north of Kbargeh, and that this district appears to have a considerable water supply that can be reached by ordinary appliances, is also of importance. This district is some 15 miles in length by 1 to 1 1/2 in breadth.
A considerable number of new alum beds have been discovered, some portions of which contain workable proportions of cobalt. Cobalic alum had previously been found in Dakhleh only.
Considerable beds of phosphates have also been discovered in Khargeh as well as in Dakhleh.

The water supply at the Deishar greatly in- creased on being opened up, and so far as can be ascertained the level at which the water now stands corresponds nearly with that of the ancient Roman water channels at the same place. This is of great importance, as it tends to disprove allegations to the effect that the level has sunk since the Roman occupation.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRUST AND INVESTMENT.
div.p: The subscriptions at Martin's Bank, London, on the 10th int., for the Egyptian Trust and Investment, Limited, amounted to 1,012,087 shares.

It is hoped that the allotments for Egypt will be posted in the first half of next week. The office of the company at Alexandria is working day and night in order to cope with the glut of applications.

div.head: GUM ARABIC.
div.p: At auction in London last week the small supplies brougnt forward attracted little atten- tion and practically all were bought to or with- drawn. The offerings comprised 263 bales Sudan, 68 packages Scented Aden, and 6 cases Oomra. 3 cases Persian sold at 23s. for palish sorts.

div.head:
EDEN PALACE HOTEL.
CAIRO.
div.p: Open all the year round.
Electric light.- Lift.- Moderate charge

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: A great lull has generally preceded an im- portant battle. The present lull, however, is, it is confidently hoped, the prelude to a great peace. There are certainly "pourparlers" going on, but the secret is well-kept. As it is long in the hatching, let us hope it will be a well- considered and lasting one. Meantime, finan- cial affairs are still in the expectant attitude, and markets have a halting tendency.

Although money has been "wanted," the Bank directors have reflected the general position, and declared no alteration in the Bank rate, which still stands at 2 1/2 per cent. minimum, a good rate for helping commercial enter- prise. It would appear that the Government decline to be frightened by the "Brighton breakers," and intend to continue to navigate the ship of State, at any rate while foreign affairs are in their present liquid position ; hence the ill effects of a prospective General Election came only to pass away.

Egyptian Companies which have come out, are hatched more or less "fully fledged," and they all seem likely to be able to survive the early stages of their career. Their future will depend upon the uses to which they put the money the public have entrusted to them.

In Egyptian stocks, as stated before, the new issue rush is being overdone, and too many new things are being hurried on the heels of one another. There is no doubt plenty of scope in Egypt for all of them, but a little more time might be given for digestion, or the appetite may be spoiled.

There is not much of interest to report with regard to the past week's stock markets, for, although the tone remains steady, business has been on a very small scale. Tho most active point has been the new Japanese 4 1/2 per cent. issue, to which the dealings have been large. The market was somewhat over-sold before the allotment, and found itself short of stock, and the premium has in consequence been well maintained above 2.
In Home Government securities the uncer- tainty of the political situation has checked business, and the prices have eased off somewhat.

In the Egyptian market the rise in National and Agricultural Banks still goes on, and the Agriculturals, in spite of the coming large increase of capital referred to last week, are firm at 13 15/16, which looks high enough, whilst Nationals are almost 28. Daira Sanieh shares were a feature yesterday, rising to 27 1/2. Other prices are practically unchanged. In the mining section, prices have given way again ; the revival of interest in Kaffirs has usurped the attention of dealers.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINES.
div.p: A London correspondent writes :—

What is happening in the Egyptian section of the Mining market? It presented on ap- pearance of great strength a week or two ago, and it seemed impossible to fix a limit to which prices might go. Then, with surprising sud- denness, comes a fall in Nile Valleys to 2 1/2, Block E.s to 19/16 and North Niles to 1 1/2, with the rest of the list proportionately weak. Naturally, after the bright promise of the last few weeks, people are asking for an explanation. The suggestions offered are of varied nature. In one quarter it is supposed that a crushing, the declaration of which is expected shortly, is likely to turn out badly. Elsewhere it is said that at one of the properties where rich quartz has been met with, it has now been definitely ascertained that the main body of the ore is barren. There may be some foundation for these rumours or there may not be. The more likely explanation of the fall, probably, is that various dealers have "ratted," and it has been impossible to continue the pool in certain shares. The position is not a very satisfactory one from the point of view of the general pu- blic, I fear.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: (du 5 au 13 avril)

La semaine avait débuté par une hauss générale, particulièrement sensible pour les valeurs de premier ordre. Forts de nouvelles semi-officieuses répandues pour pousser les cours, certains spéculateurs s'étaient lancés à corps perdu. Le résultat d'une telle imprudence ne s'est pas fait attendre: le marché, surchargé de petits acheteurs incapables de mainten r leurs positions, n'a pas tardé à réactionne; ceux qui s'étaient trop avancés ont dû liquider. C'est ce qui a déterminé, avec l'énervement de la place, la faiblesse de ces derniers jours.

La corbeille, une fois débarrassée de ce trop plein, a repris à la suite d'importants rachat; mais une nouvelle réaction est à craindre d'u moment à l'autre. Les hauts cours entraîneront nécessairement des réalisations et de noubreuses positions devront coûté que coûte à quider à la fin du mois.

Somme toute, le marché en lui-même n'est pas mauvais et le numéraire abonde ici. La 1 preuve en est qu'à elle seule la souscription da Trust a produit en une journée et demie la jolie somme de 1 million de livres sterling. 111 faut dire que le calme plat qui ne cesse de régner sur les contrats depuis quelques mois est un facteur important de prospérité pour la corbeille des valeurs. Bon nombre de courtiers en coton ne sachant que faire à la corbeille des marchandises se rejettent sur les valeurs dont a manipulation leur donne plus de bénéfices. L fermeture de l'après-midi a bien, si l'on veut, un peu ralenti les arbitrages avec Londres et Paris, mais cette mesure a eu en définitive plus d'avantages que d'inconvénients: les esprits échauffés durant la matinée ont ainsi le temps d de se calmer et de réfléchir durant l'après-g midi ; c'est ce qui a empêché d'exagérer le mou- vement sur certaines valeurs, comme cela avait eu lieu récemment. Les contrats suivront d'aii-d leurs le même horaire à partir du 22 courant.

Les valeurs qui ont été le plus en faveur b durant la semaine sont l'Agricole, la Daïra et la Banque Nationale sur lesquelles s'est concen- trée toute l'attention du marché. Les voleurs de e second ordre ont été par le fait même un peu négligées.

L'Agricole débute à 13 9/16, atteint 14 et clôture à 13 3/8 en bonne demande. L'Assem-t blée du 1er mai discutera les projets que nous avons énumérés dans notre chronique de la I semaine passée, à savoir la réduction du taux I maximum de l'intérêt 9 0/0 à 8 0/0 par an dès que les avances faites aux fellahs atteindront d un capital de L.E.. 7.000.000, J'émission de nouvelles actions au pair avec droit de pré-8 férence pour les porteurs des actions anciennes, e l'émission d'obligations jusqu'à concurrence de £ 6.570 000, y compris celles déjà émises.

De 26 1,2 au début la Daïra monte à 27 7/8 pour finir à 27 3/8 acheteurs. On attend avec impatience le bilan qui sera communiqué à l'assemblée du 29 avril et qu'on annonce comme très avantageux. Les rumeurs mises en circu- lation à propos d'offres faites à la Daïra pour sa liquidation ne présentant rien d'officiel, nous nous abstenons de les publier.

La Banque Nationale ouvre à 27 1/2, atteint 28 et retombe à 27 7/16 ferme. On annonce comme probable une nouvelle émission de 50,000 t actions de £10, émises à £20à raison de 1 titre nouveau pour 5 anciens.

Un des premiers actes du nouveau comité des courtiers en valeurs a été l'admission de la Land Bank à la cote officielle. Le cours inscrit à 9 1/2 a clôturé à 9 13/16 acheteurs. On émettrait prochainement 2.500.000 £ d'c- bligations.
L'Investment a été également admis. Il dé-I bute à 2 5/16 pour finir à 2 3/16 avec affaires limitées.
Après avoir ouvert à 1 5/16, l'Estates a flé-S chi jusqu'à 1 5/82, cours auquel il clôture 2 vendeurs.
Oublié d'abord à 1 1/8, l'Oasis revient à flot I à 1 1/4, prix de clôture. Une source abondante aurait été découverte à Kharga à une profondeur de 145 pieds.

En Markets les transactions ont été nom breuses et de ce chef le cours remonte de 22/9 à 26/6 pour clôturer à 25/6.Cette reprise est dûe en partie à la diminution de la peste bovine et en partie à une concession d'abattoirs que les Markets obtiendraient dans les villages. La Delta Light, ferme au début à 14 7/16- 14 1/2, fléchit plus tard à 14 3/16 offerte. La Deferred tombe également de 15 1/8 à 14 1/2 sans affaires.
Le cours de la Banque d'Athènes a fluctué entre 117 et 116 pour clôturer à 116 1/2. Le mouvement sur cette valeur s'est bien ralenti depuis quelque temps, mais on s'attend à une reprise.
La Béhéra fléchit encore de 49 à 48 sans affaires.

De 3 9/16 à l'ouverture la Delta Land monte à 3 7/8 pour finir à 3 13/16 acheteurs. Le public se plaint de la manière que cette société se propose de faire sa prochaine émission; celle-ci serait réservée aux actionnaires inscrits dans ses livres, de telle sorte que les porteurs éventuels qui ne seraient pas arrivés à transférer leurs certificats du nom de leurs vendeurs en leurs noms propres ne pourraient souscrire à la nouvelle émission. Mais on espère que, vu les circonstances, la Société fera droit aux justes desiderata du public.
La Salt & Soda passe de 39/6 à 40/3, mais retombe à 39/3 en clôture.
Les Eaux du Caire haussent graduellement de 1,245 à 1,280 acheteurs, prix de clôture. L'Alexandria Water fléchit de 16 1/2 à 16 7/16 vendeurs.
De 5,9 les Cotton Mills retombent à 5/6. L'Anglo-American Nile fléchit de 6 1/4 à 5 3/4 par suite d'importantes réalisations, mais elle reprend en clôture à 5 7/8.
La Nungovich fluctue entre 10 3/8 et 10 1/4 avec affaires très limitées.
Les obligations Crédit Foncier Egyptien haussent de 338 à 351 pour revenir à 336 en clôture. La Nouvelle Emission monte de 274 1/2 $279,

Il faut noter encore la hausse remarquable des actions Crédit Foncier Egyptien qui de, 770 montent à 825. En Parts de Fondateu qui avaient été traitées au début à 5,200, o clôture à 6,900 francs. On attribue cette hausse à une entente entre le Crédit Foncier et la New Daira Sanieh Cy. pour la liquidation de cette dernière.
(Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)
A part le Crédit Foncier Egyptien, la Daïra et la Salt and Soda, tout le reste du marché est calme
De nombreuses transactions ont eu lieu en actions Crédit Foncier dont le cours atteint 858 et en Obligations qui sont fermes à 336.
La Daïra qui avait débuté faible à 27 3/16 reprend rapidement à 27 7/16 avec beaucoup d'animation.
Quant à la Salt & Soda on est tombé de 39/3 à 38 pour reprendre légèrement à 38/3 en clô-
ture.
L'Agricole hausse à 13 7/16,l'Oasis à 15/16, la Delta Light à 14 3/16.
Par contre l'Investment fléchit à 2 5/32, l'Estate à 1 1/8, la Khedivial Mail à 4 5/16 et les Privilégiées Tramways à 147.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: THEATRE ZIZINIA
CENDRILLON

L'énumération des costumes des amateurs dans "Cendrillon" n'ayant pu trouver place dans notre compte-rendu d'hier, nous croyons devoir donner aujourd'hui un aperçu des magnifiques toilettes portées par les dames dans cette soirée inoubliable :

Mme Charles Bacos en merveilleux costume de brocart d'or, garni de perles; Mlle de Tschudi en costume de soie bleu-ciel avec tablier pailleté ; Mme Critchley en costume de damas jaune pailleté, garni de dentelles; Mme de Planta en robe princesse de satin blanc, entièrement recouverte de perles, avec un voile d'argent sur les épaules et dans les cheveux un diadème d'étoiles; Mme Clataway Bey en robe de satin blanc brodée d'or avec riche manteau de soie brochée; Mme Alfred de Menasce en admirable costume de brocart bleu pâle pailleté d'argent et garni de perles, avec une parure de brillants; Mine Jacques Suarès en brocart rose, pailleté et garni de dentelles d'argent; Mme Gustave Suarès en brocart. mauve pailleté; Mile Stagni en brocart d'or garni de perles et satin blanc; Mile Fenderl en robe de soie bleu-ciel pailleté ; Mlle Jeanne de Zogheb en taffetas blanc brodé d'or; Mlles Dahan en taffetas richement brodé; Miles du Boys en satin liberty pailleté or et dentelles ; Mile de Humboldt en costume d'une dame de la Cour de Louis XIII en velours bleu.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT.
Liverpool 6 April.

The market has been very quiet this week, and the sales small. Spinners continue their hand to mouth policy, and only buy for im mediate requirements. Prices are in favor of the buyer, but quotations are unchanged. Only a moderate business has been done in futures. The following are the latest values:- April 6.44 June 6.33 Aug. 6.26
May 6.39 July 6.29 Nov. 6.17

American Futures. The market this week has experienced several unimportant fluctuations, prices have generally had a slightly hardening tendency, and to-day's closing values are 3 @ 5 points higher than those of last Thursday. Speculation is completely in abeyance pending further information re- garding the progress of planting, the use of fertilizers, and the estimated reduction of the area under cultivation At the present time planting is backward, and the general weather conditions are less favorable than at this time last season.
The latest quotations are, delivery: April 4.14 July/Aug. 4.19 Nov./Dec. 4.22 Apl./May 4.14 Aug./Sep. 4.20 Dec./Jan. 4.23 May/June 4.16 Sep./Oct. 4.21 Jan./Feb. 4.24 June/July 4.18 Oct./Nov. 4.21.

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.-We would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £1 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad-street E.C., acts as London agency to the Chanber.
